document.description: A commissioning toolkit for England
document.body:
This practical toolkit has been written to guide primary care trusts, practice based commissioners and local authority children's trusts in commissioning maternity services and providing support for parents during the transition to parenthood. High quality accessible services, as set out in the National service framework for children, young people and maternity services, can make a significant contribution to maternal and infant health and to the government's broader health targets. Payment by results and new commissioning arrangements must be used to support services that improve health outcomes and well-being, and enable women to make choices.

Case studies throughout the toolkit illustrate innovative ways of improving access, quality and choice and making good use of the maternity services workforce.

document.body:
More for your money is a short guide to achieving better outcomes from NHS procurement and how social enterprises as suppliers can help you achieve this. It includes case studies that illustrate how contracting with social enterprises has benefited a range of NHS organisations, as well as some best practice examples from across the wider public sector. Although much of the guide refers to the procurement environment in England, the principles of successful procurement from social enterprises apply equally in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, and this guide complements work taking place across the UK.

This guide does not suggest that social enterprise should have an unfair advantage over other suppliers in the bidding process. Rather, that social enterprises have a valuable part to play within the context of a diverse range of suppliers. Of course, they will have to prove this to the purchaser.

This is only a short introduction to procuring from social enterprises but there are a range of resources available if you want to take the next step (see the Further resources section on page 34).

]]>

document.title: More responsive public services? A guide to commissioning migrant and refugee community organisations
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,SERVICE PROVISION,POPULATIONS SERVED,ETHNIC MINORITY GROUPS,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,GENERAL,THIRD SECTOR,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: This guide sets out the case for migrant community organisations as providers of commissioned public services, both to show commissioners why they should consider them and to help the organisations themselves understand what their roles could be.
document.body:
Migration is changing the face of Britain's population. It has accounted for about half of Britain's population growth in the last ten years. In the last five years, about 200,000 people have been accepted as refugees and are now settled in Britain on a long-term basis.

Many of these new communities have formed new organisations. They provide vital support services to their communities. But such services are often not part of any wider local or national stucture for service provision. Several groups are now providing more fully developed services - and many more would like to do so. Among other benefits, being part of a formal structure enables groups both to improve the quality of their services, and to prove that they are doing so. Becoming providers of publicly funded services may also have wider benefits in helping the integration of migrant communities. 

This guide covers a comprehensive range of relevant services, including accommodation, training legal advice, physical and mental health and other support services. The guide is about public services which are commissioned from third parties - normally through competition - and operated under legal contracts. It is not about grant-aid for the third party organisations.

The guide's main aim is to set out the case for these minority ethnic organisations as providers of commissioned public service, both to show commissioners why they should consider them and to help the organisations themselves to understand and form their own views on what their potential roles could be. In this respect the guide's aim is to change the climate of opinion - on both sides of the commissioning process - as well as to show how such a change fits in with wider government reform of the public services. 

]]>

document.description: Toolkit to enable NHS organisations and the pharmaceutical industry to work together in the interests of patients.
document.body:
This toolkit is designed to help the NHS meet the challenges of a rapidly evolving health service by providing practical advice and tools, based on best practice, so that joint working projects with the pharmaceutical industry can be set up rapidly and effectively, reducing duplication of effort, increasing efficiency and minimising unnecessary workload and stress.

The purpose of this toolkit is to:

  • encourage NHS organisations and staff to consider joint working as a realistic option for the delivery of high-quality healthcare and a way to drive efficiency in the delivery of services in both primary and secondary care
  • provide the necessary information and have easy access to the tools which will help to enter into joint working.

The initial version of the toolkit was published in March 2008. Following feedback from users, the toolkit has been updated to include some new templates as well as more examples of good practice for reference. This toolkit should be used in conjunction with the document “Best practice guidance for joint working between the NHS and the pharmaceutical industry”.

document.title: National commissioning for treatment refractory obsessive compulsive disorder and body dysmorphic disorder
document.publisher: South London and Maudsley NHS Trust; Institute of Psychiatry
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MENTAL HEALTH,ADULT CONDITIONS,OBSESSIVE COMPULSIVE DISORDER,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,ACUTE SERVICES,DISEASE/CONDITION GROUPS,MENTAL HEALTH PROBLEMS,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,GENERAL,SPECIALIST AND TERTIARY CARE]]>
document.description: These web pages provide details of the services on offer for OCD and some of the details about how they can be accessed.
document.body:
Most people suffering from OCD find their lives completely dominated by this problem and are unable to access appropriate treatment because of funding issues. For the most severely affected individuals there is now a system for referral to national specialist centres which does not require approval by local funding agencies such as the primary care trust. Because funding is provided centrally, patients who meet certain criteria will automatically be accepted for relatively rapid treatment for the obsessive compulsive disorder. This specifically means that people who are accepted by the National Specialist Service will be offered evidence based treatment including cognitive behaviour therapy, medication and possibly a combination.

These web pages give details of the services on offer and some of the details about how they can be accessed. The National Commissioning Group for Highly Specialist Services (NCGHSS) of the Department of Health has commissioned a service for the treatment refractory Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) or Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). The funding for such patients is by the Department of Health. Patients who do not meet such criteria can still be referred by the normal process and funded by their PCTs. The referral pathways and criteria which they have to meet are described in the article.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,OBESITY,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,POPULATIONS,SETTINGS,ORGANISATIONS,NATIONAL ORGANISATIONS,PUBLIC HEALTH ORGANISATIONS,METHODS,MEASUREMENT,GEOGRAPHY,REGIONAL VARIATIONS,COMMISSIONING,DATASETS,TOOLKITS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,DECEMBER 2010]]>
document.description: The National Obesity Observatory e-atlases are interactive mapping tools for the analysis of data on the prevalence of obesity and its determinants at Local Authority (LA) and Primary Care Trust (PCT) level in England.
document.body:
The National Obesity Observatory e-atlases are interactive mapping tools for the analysis of data on the prevalence of obesity and its determinants at Local Authority (LA) and Primary Care Trust (PCT) level in England.

The new child e-atlases enable users to view and compare data at PCT and LA level, for both single and dual maps. The adult e-atlases allow comparison at LA level for both single and dual maps.

The single map e-atlases enable users to make regional and national comparisons for a wide range of indicators.

The dual map e-atlases enable users to compare indicators including prevalence of childhood obesity using data from the National Child Measurement Programme (NCMP) with, for example, local area deprivation scores and NCMP participation rate. The adult dual map e-atlas includes indicators on physical activity, prevalence of type 2 diabetes and incidence of colorectal cancer.

In the dual map e-atlases the degree of correlation between selected variables is presented with a scatter plot and accompanying statistical equations. Users must be aware of the limitations and caveats associated with the data to understand any relationship which may be shown between data in the e-atlases. Click here for more information on these statistical methods

A metadata and guidance document is available for each indicator providing information on the data source and an explanation of any limitations that should be considered when undertaking analysis.

More indicators will continue to be added to this tool.

]]>

document.description: A key policy objective in most publicly financed health care systems is to allocate resources according to need. Many jurisdictions implement this policy objective through needbased allocation models. To date, no gold standard exists for selecting need indicators. In the absence of a gold standard, sensitivity of the choice of need indicators is of concern. The primary objective of this study was to assess the consistency and plausibility of estimates of per capita relative need for health services across Canadian provinces based on different need indicators.

document.description: Date reviewed: 29-03-10
document.body:
111-1Needs assessment

Date reviewed: 29-03-10

 

 Definition

'Health needs assessment is a systematic method for reviewing the health issues facing a population, leading to agreed priorities and resource allocation that will improve health and reduce inequalities.' (1)

 

It forms part of the World class commissioning competency to manage knowledge and assess needs:


'Manage knowledge and undertake robust and regular needs assessments that establish a full understanding of current and future local health needs....

Commissioning decisions should be based on sound knowledge and evidence. By identifying current needs and anticipating future trends, PCTs will be able to ensure that current and future commissioned services address and respond to the needs of the whole population, especially those whose needs are greatest. The JSNA [Joint Strategic Needs Assessment] will form one part of this assessment, but when operated at world class levels will require more and richer data, knowledge and intelligence than the minimum laid out within the proposed duty of a JSNA.' (2)

 

Guidance/Tools

Department of Health


Meeting the health needs of children and young people: a guide for commissioners. (Healthcare for London, November 2009)

Transforming community services: enabling new patterns of provision (Department of Health, January 2009)

Sexual health needs assessments (SHNA): a 'how to guide'. (August 2007)

Understanding and planning for the needs of individuals and of the local population. Chapter 3 in Commissioning framework for health and well-being (March 2007)

Diabetes commissioning toolkit. - includes guidance on needs assessment. (November 2006)

CAMHS needs assessment for primary care trusts. - Dear Colleague Letter (March 2005)

Guidance on developing prison health needs assessments and health improvement plans. (January 2002)

Toolkit for health care needs assessment in prisons (January 2000)

 

NICE (former Health Development Agency publications)

Health needs assessment: a practical guide. (2005)

Clarifying approaches to health needs assessment, health impact assessment, integrated impact assessment, health equity audit and race equality impact assessment. (2005)

Clarifying health impact assessment, integrated impact assessment and health needs assessment. (2004)

Health needs assessment workbook. (2003)

 

Care Services Efficiency Delivery

Anticipating future needs toolkit. (September 2007)

 

Care Services Improvement Partnership

Public health tools and techniques and their application to integrated services. Chapter 4 in The role of public health in supporting the development of integrated services.  (May 2007) - This publication has been produced to highlight how Public Health can significantly support local government and health professionals to identify need, support prioritisation and develop integrated services to maximise health and well-being.

 

The role of needs analysis in developing a commissioning strategy. - Chapter 5 of the Commissioning e-book.

 

ERPHO (Eastern Region Public Health Observatory)

What is health needs assessment? - PowerPoint presentation

Primary data needed for a strategic needs assessment.

 

Every Child Matters 

'Turning the curve' toolkit: practical application of results based accountability. (August 2006) - This toolkit includes guidance, pro-forma and case studies. It has been provided for children's trusts and other interested agencies to explain the 'how' of needs assessment. It can be used as it stands or adapted for local purposes.

Developing health assessment for black and minority ethnic groups: summary. (2000)

Health needs assessment toolkit. (2002)

Pharmecuetical needs assesment toolkit. (December 2004)

LHO (London Health Observatory)

London Practice Profiles Tool

 

 Trent Research & Development Support Unit

 National Public Health Service for Wales

 World Health Organization

Reports and Consultation Documents

Health needs of gypsies and travellers. (Improvement and Development Agency, page last updated 23 March 2010)

Skin conditions in the UK: a health care needs assessment. (University of Nottingham, Centre of Evidence Based Dermatology, September 2009)

 

Need-based resource allocation: different need indicators, different results? (BMC Health Services Research, July 2009)

 

Improving eye health services. This document provides advice on how PCTs can: assess current performance; identify vision for the future and commission services that meet the needs of the local community. (Department of Health, July 2009)

document.description: The National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) has worked with stakeholders to co-produce this document. It sets out guidance for PCT commissioners on implementing the Never Events policy and builds on existing processes and mechanisms.
document.body:
Never Events are serious, largely preventable patient safety incidents that should not occur if the available preventative measures have been implemented.

The National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) has worked with stakeholders to co-produce this document. It sets out guidance for PCT commissioners on implementing the Never Events policy and builds on existing processes and mechanisms. It covers the Never Events policy, process and tools for implementation by PCTs, the core list of Never Events and actions providers and PCTs are expected to take if a Never Event occurs.

]]>

document.description: Date reviewed: 01-10-10
document.body:
111-1New providers in the NHS market: independent sector


Date reviewed: 01-10-10

Definition

'Independent Sector healthcare organisations provide greater scope to introduce new and innovative ways of delivering healthcare to NHS patients by adapting the traditional NHS model to suit local healthcare needs. Some Centres are refurbished sections of existing hospitals, or new buildings and some are mobile units that travel around the country. Patients treated at any NHS Treatment Centre that is managed by an independent healthcare company are still NHS patients. Care and treatment is free and patients can expect the same level of service they would expect from the NHS. GP or local support services can give patients information about the choices that are available.' (1)

'Treatment centres are run either by the NHS or commissioned by primary care trusts (PCTs) from independent sector providers. Although capacity in the NHS is growing fast, it cannot grow fast enough to meet the ... next target of a maximum 18 week wait from referral to treatment by December 2008. This is why extra capacity is being sought through independent sector-run Treatment centres.' (2)

document.title: NHS Next Stage Review: First report of session 2008-09
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STRATEGIC COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,MANAGE SYSTEMS,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES]]>
document.description: Volume 1: Report, together with formal minutes
document.body:
The House of Commons Health Select Committee has published its report on Lord Darzi's Next Stage Review. The report is in two parts: Volume 1: Report, together with formal minutes and Volume 2: Oral and written evidence.

The report describes the main proposals contained in the NSR and witnesses' responses to them. Chapter 2 describes the process leading up to the publication of the NSR. Chapter 3 then looks in general terms at witnesses' concerns about some of the proposals, in particular whether they are likely to be implemented successfully. Chapters 4 to 8 then addres the most significant proposals in the NSR. It examines in particular the Department's proposals to:

  • improve quality
  • extend 'patient choice' and 'personalisation' in primary healthcare
  • establish an NHS constitution
  • improve workforce planning and leadership in the NHS
]]>

document.description: Resources to support the National Knowledge Week 18-22 June 2007 on NHS System Reform
document.body:
111-1NHS System Reform: PCTs as commissionersContributory author: Ruth Thorlby, King's Fund

Better commissioning is a key element of the current NHS reform programme. It is also one of the most recent to be developed, with the initial changes to Primary Care Trusts (PCTs) proposed in 2005 (including halving the number of PCTs to create larger, more powerful commissioning organisations) (1). That reorganisation took place in October 2006 and since then PCTs have been issued with a stream of guidance from the Department of Health, most of it aimed at improving the commissioning of hospital or specialist services (2, 3, 4, 5) and more recently, better commissioning of health improvement and wider preventative services in the local community or in partnership with local government (6).

As a consequence of the relatively recent nature of this strand of reform, most of the literature takes the form of policy analysis, as empirically based evaluation has yet to materialise. The current attention being paid by government to improving the skills and scope of commissioners in PCTs is welcomed by many commentators who point out that this has been a neglected area of health reform until recently (7, 8, 9) and that previous attempts at improving commissioning at primary care level in the 1990s were only partially successful (7).

Many of the analyses attempt to define the scope of commissioning, (7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and point out that the current vision for commissioning represents a big expansion from previous conceptions of commissioning which focused more narrowly on purchasing or contracting health services (10). The identification of health needs and local demand for health services is seen as a key function (7, 8, 9, 10, 11), followed by purchasing and negotiating contracts (8, 9, 10, 11), creating and shaping the market for different providers (7), holding the market to account (through contracts, for example) (7), monitoring the effectiveness of providers (8, 9, 11 ), engaging with the local community (8, 10) and being held to account by the local community (7) and other local stakeholders (10).

The context in which this commissioning function is being carried out is also considered to be important. Commissioners have to ensure that patients are able to exercise a choice of provider (7, 8) and act as a counterbalance to the acute sector, which faces strong incentives to expand provision under payment by results (7). There are also different interpretations of the overall aims of commissioning, with some identifying the ‘containment’ of demand for hospital services and value for money as a priority (9) while others see the current commissioning reforms as a unique opportunity to link health promotion and prevention with the core business of commissioning hospital services (12).

The bulk of the policy analysis contained in the literature is devoted to identifying the key challenges to be overcome and, in some cases, suggesting solutions. Lack of clinical engagement with commissioning is identified by several analyses as having been a problem in the past (8, 11) and not all are convinced that the current solution on offer- Practice Based Commissioning- will on its own deliver more engaged GPs (11). Other suggestions include a new tier of clinical support for GPs engaged in Practice Based Commissioning and the creation of a ‘clinical executive’ for the senior management of PCTs (13).

Several analyses draw attention to the improvement needed in the information at the disposal of commissioners and the skills required to analyse the information (7, 8, 9, 10, 14). Another theme that emerges is the need to radically improve the scope and effectiveness of commissioners’ engagement with the public (7, 10).

There are also calls for greater clarity from the government about the future scope of private or third sector providers and their relationship with commissioners (15) and greater clarity about what constitutes “success” for commissioning more generally (8).

document.description: Resources to support the National Knowledge Week 18-22 June 2007 on NHS System Reform
document.body:
111-1NHS System Reform: practice based commissioningContributory author: Ruth Thorlby, King's Fund


Practice Based Commissioning is a mechanism to devolve commissioning to GP level, by offering GP practices the chance to hold notional budgets, redesign services to be more efficient and convenient for patients and retain some or all of any savings realised for reinvestment in the practice. Although the details of Practice Based Commissioning only began to emerge in 2004, the commitment to GP-led commissioning dates back to 1998 and many of the ideas come from the experience of GP Fundholding (and other variants) in the 1990s  (1, 2, 3).

The potential of Practice Based Commissioning (PBC) to deliver a range of benefits, including more appropriate referrals to secondary care, alternative diagnostic tests and treatments delivered outside hospital and more streamlined care ‘pathways’ for patients has been recognised (2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7). However, the policy is still in a very early stage of development: although the option to get involved in PBC has been available to GPs since 2005, a target for a very initial engagement by all GP practices with PBC was set for the end of 2006, known as ‘universal coverage’, which is monitored by the uptake of incentive payments rather than service redesign (1,4).

To date, therefore, there has been very little systematic evidence of how well PBC is working nationally because the policy is so new.  Nevertheless, there is some partial evidence available. The Audit Commission looked at the experience of GPs who were ‘early adopters’ of PBC and found that while PBC had the potential to drive positive change, considerable challenges remained, for example, engaging GPs and PCTs needing to deliver high quality and timely information about service usage and budgets to GPs (4).

Other studies have used survey data to build up a picture about implementation. The most recent, a survey of GPs and GP practice managers, found that while commitment to the policy as a whole was widespread, there were complaints about poor support from PCTs, poor quality or absent information delivered to GPs and a perception that there had yet to be any real impact on care (1). An earlier survey focused on the extent of patient and public involvement with PBC and found that this was an area which needed further development, as over 70% of responding PCTs reported that there was little or no involvement(8).

Some examples of what PBC can achieve in the form of simple case studies are available (3, 5, 9) with quantified evidence, for instance, of reductions in inappropriate referrals and new alternative services (although some of these examples also coincide or build on earlier initiatives, such as GPs with Special Interests GPSIs) (5).

Much more evidence is now available about the effect of the precursors to PBC (Fundholding and  Total Purchasing Pilots) (10, 11). This evidence suggests that Fundholding, for example, did appear to lead to more efficiency (reductions in elective referrals and some reductions in prescription costs) and better quality for patients in the form of shorter waits, but there was also evidence of higher management and transaction costs and greater inequalities in access to care between patients in Fundholding and non-Fundholding practices (10,11).


References:   

1. Lewis, Richard and Curry, Natasha and Dixon, Michael. Practice Based Commissioning: from good idea to effective practice
London: King’s Fund, 2007 [Full text]

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,ACUTE SERVICES,PATIENT AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,ENGAGING THE PUBLIC,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,CASE STUDIES]]>
document.body:
This is a report on one of the Organisational Development projects carried out by the NHS Centre for Involvement. Each of these projects looked at involvement at both a strategic and service improvement level. At the strategic level, an organisational diagnostic was conducted to find examples of good practice in involvement within a trust, and also to identify priority areas for improvement. Focusing on organisational systems, processes and resources, the diagnostic looked at how involvement can be mainstreamed across an organisation to become part of everyday practice.  At a service improvement level, a specific piece of work was designed to model best practice in involvement around a priority issue or with a specific patient/user group.

The project undertaken with Tower Hamlets Primary Care Trust focused on commissioning urgent care.

]]>

document.title: NHS trust accounts: a guide for non-executives
document.topics: <![CDATA[ FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT,PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT,FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,KNOWLEDGE AND DATA MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: This guide focuses on the four primary statements and notes to the accounts, which make up part of NHS trust accounts, as specified by the NHS trust Manual for Accounts.
document.body:
NHS organisations have a statutory duty to produce annual accounts (also known as financial statements) and an annual report. The trust board is required to formally approve the accounts once they have been audited and therefore it is vital that Non-Executive Directors (NEDs) understand them. Alongside this formal requirement, understanding the annual accounts is imperative if NEDs are to fully appreciate the financial health of their organisation.

The format of the accounts is specified by the NHS trust Manual for Accounts and consists of: four primary statements (Income and Expenditure Account; Balance Sheet; Cash Flow Statement; Statement of Total Recognised Gains and Losses); notes to the accounts; statement on internal control; directors' statement of responsibilities; and the auditor's report.

This guide focuses on the four primary statements and the notes to the accounts. Each primary statement and the key notes to the accounts are explained using an illustrative set of accounts. It is intended that NEDs will use the guide as a source of reference to look at if additional understanding is required for a particular aspect of the accounts. The guide also includes some questions that NEDs should consider before approving the annual accounts. 

]]>

document.title: No Patient Left Behind: how can we ensure world class primary care for black and minority ethnic people?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,RACE EQUALITY,COMMISSIONING,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,NEEDS ASSESSMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,POPULATIONS SERVED,ETHNIC MINORITY GROUPS,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,ENGAGING THE PUBLIC,CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: Report of the group chaired by Professor Mayur Lakhani CBE
document.body:
Fair and equal access to services is a right of every NHS patient, regardless of their ethnic origin or where they live in the UK. Sometimes this means providing additional or different kinds of services, for example professional interpreters and patient advocates, to make sure all sectors of society are able to benefit from the NHS in the same way and to help patients make informed choices about their treatment and care options.

It is up to individual PCTs and GP practices to work out the make-up of their local patient populations and design and commission services that best meet their needs, however this isn’t happening as well at it should. The first national GP patient survey, conducted in January 2007, found that a large proportion of BME patients, particularly Bangladeshi patients, are less happy with access to primary care services than white patients, sometimes even within the same practice.

Therefore the Secretary of State for Health asked Professor Mayur Lakhani to set up a review team to find out more and suggest a way forward. The team visited GP surgeries and PCTs in areas of the country where there are lots of BME patients, and talked to staff and patients about the local health services on offer. It also set up focus groups of BME patients to get more information and it looked at key research evidence.

The team’s conclusion is that there is a mismatch between the health needs and requirements of BME people and the services on offer, leading to dissatisfaction and unmet need.

]]>

document.title: Not NICE : can PCTs engage patients and the public in commissioning new health technologies?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,PATIENT AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,ENGAGING THE PUBLIC,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.body:
The availability of expensive new health technologies, especially new drugs, combined with the increasing public awareness of them, presents a significant set of problems for local healthcare commissioners.

Primary Care Trusts (PCTs) have a triple challenge with regard to commissioning these new technologies: to be rational, transparent and locally accountable for their decisions. This study aimed to examine how PCTs tackle the task of engaging patients and the public in decisions about which new technologies should be funded. It examined any mechanisms developed and the problems encountered.

The project was in two parts:

• a review of existing evidence

• a small-scale qualitative interview study with key staff in four primary care trusts.

The project research was funded by IMS Health, and was carried out in 2007. It therefore preceded the World Class Commissioning framework, the publication of the NHS Next Stage Review, and the government’s review of co-payments. These developments have made the study’s findings especially relevant to the current context.

The report was published in January 2009.

]]>

document.description: This podcast discussion is led by Janet Crampton of CSIP and brings together four leading thinkers and practitioners in the development of outcome-based commissioning. It includes the transcript.
document.body:
This podcast discussion is led by Janet Crampton of CSIP and brings together four leading thinkers and practitioners in the development of outcome-based commissioning. It includes the transcript.

The panel consists of Professor Andrew Kerslake from the Institute of Public Care at Oxford Brookes University, Peter Mason, chief executive of the Centre for Public Innovation, independent consultant Lucianne Sawyer, who is president of the UK Homecare Association, and Rob Williams, director of Creative Partnerships.

They discuss the culture change and local leadership required to move from an output to outcome-based approach and potential obstacles such as current infrastructure and ways of working. The panel also talk about the legal aspects and what an outcome-based contract might look like.

 

]]>

document.description: Using the Outcomes versus Expenditure Tool you can compare expenditure and other aspects of services with a number of outcome measures at primary care trust (PCT) level.
document.body:
Using the Outcomes versus Expenditure Tool you can compare expenditure and other aspects of services with a number of outcome measures at primary care trust (PCT) level.

As a commissioner, the Outcomes versus Expenditure Tool – Maternity and Newborn allows you to pinpoint opportunities to improve the quality of outcomes and productivity in your local area for maternity and neonatal services. You can use the tool to:

  • Compare expenditure within a fixed area with service performance in terms of health and wellbeing outcomes.
  • Identify where either your expenditure or performance is significantly different to that of other organisations including your statistical neighbours.
  • See where you are an outlier.
  • Find better performing organisations you might be able to learn from about what works well and how you can replicate it.

You will also find the tool useful if you are a provider of maternity services, as a means of sparking discussion with local commissioners about ways to improve services.

]]>

document.title: Palliative care services for children and young people in England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,POPULATIONS AND SETTINGS,SERVICE PROVISION,POLICY,CHILDREN & YOUNG PEOPLE,TRANSITIONAL CARE AGE GROUP,AGE-RELATED ISSUES,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,ACUTE SERVICES,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,SERVICE PROVISION,CONTRACTING AND PROCUREMENT,POPULATIONS SERVED,PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT,FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT,CHILDREN,YOUNG PEOPLE,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,GRANTS,SPECIALIST AND TERTIARY CARE]]>
document.description: This independent review is based on findings from a wide consultation with stakeholders, including children and young people and their families, commissioners and service providers. It makes recommendations for change in access to services and for their sustainability.
document.body:
Children's palliative care is concerned with symptom control and maintaining quality of life, not just in the dying stages, but in the weeks, months and years before a child's death. Although it has been developed to support children and young people who are diagnosed with life-limiting or life-threatening conditions, there are strong overlaps between these children and those with disabilities. Children typically move into and out of different services depending on the progress of their condition. Palliative care needs therefore to form a thread through the lives of many children with severe disabilities and complex needs.

Palliative care services for children and young children have developed over the last 25 years in a largely unplanned way. Funding has also been ad hoc and often short-term. In May 2006, concern about what would happen to hospice services once the Big Lottery Fund grants finished led to the Secretary of State for Health pledging £27m over a three-year period to support children's hospices, and the commissioning of this review.

One of the main aims of the reivew has been to find a more sustainable way of developing and funding services as well as looking at the availability and accessibility of these services.

]]>

document.description: Software tool which helps PCTs use routine data to predict the risk of emergency re-admission to hospital.
document.body:
Software tool which helps PCTs use routine data to predict the risk of emergency re-admission to hospital.

PARR – short for 'Patients At Risk of Re-hospitalisation' – is a software tool that can be run daily. When an individual is admitted to hospital the tool uses the patient’s recent admissions data (up to four years) to calculate the likelihood of re-admission over the next 12 months. This takes into account factors such as prior utilisation, diagnoses and socio-demographic information and gives a high rate of predictive accuracy.

]]>

document.publisher: University of British Columbia, Centre for Human Settlements
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,COMMISSIONING,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,SERVICE PROVISION,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.body:
These web pages describe a Centre for Human Settlements project for promoting participatory budgeting (PB) in Canada. The purpose of this project is to determine the possibilities and conditions under which PB can work in Canada to revitalise local democracy and help address communities' social, economic, and environmental problems. It will aim to create avenues and opportunities for mutual learning between academics, students, political leaders, business and community organisations as they analyse existing knowledge and practice in PB, create new knowledge through experimentation, and develop models for PB that work in the Canadian context. These mutual learning processes are expected to

-- raise public awareness about budgets and the budgetary process,
-- promote citizenship,
-- build community capacity for public policy engagement,
-- enrich existing university curricula in participatory governance and planning practice, and
-- create local alliances and national networks that could support PB practices in the future.
 

These web pages also contain details of the project proposal and links to other resources on participatory budgeting.

]]>

document.description:
This guide is targeted at commissioners based in PCTs, but provides managers from all parts of the health service and their front-line staff with an effective toolkit, a ‘how to’ guide to support them as they work to engage people.
[No publication date available]
document.body:
This toolkit is primarily intended to support commissioners based in PCTs, but provides managers from all parts of the health service and their front-line staff with a guide as they work to engage people. The aims of the toolkit are to:

- Create awareness of the need for public and patient engagement within our everyday activities.
- Promote an understanding of the wider issues relating to patient and public engagement.
- Provide practical guidance to enable staff from across the NHS, and commissioners in particular, to engage patients and the public in how services are planned, developed and delivered.
- Support work to make services more accessible and appropriate to a wider group of people. To support this, the toolkit provides specific information on working with groups traditionally termed ‘hard to reach’.
- Encourage a more pro-active, developmental approach to engaging people, including establishing long-term mechanisms for engagement.
- Acknowledge existing expertise and highlight examples of good practice.
- Support PCTs to achieve World Class Commissioning.

[No publication date available]

]]>

document.description: This survey of Primary Care Trusts (PCTs) was carried out to determine their readiness to engage patients and the public in healthcare commissioning.
document.body:
While some PCTs have embarked on ambitious programmes to engage patients and the public in commissioning, many are not ready for the new challenges that confront them. They face numerous difficulties, including the following:

  1. deficiencies in financial and human resources and organisational capacity
  2. tight timescales

  3. the "mindset" of clinical staff and managers who often do not value or prioritise patient and public involvement

  4. lack of relevant data

  5. difficulties in supporting, training and motivating the public to engage with commissioning issues

  6. accessing seldom heard groups

  7. insufficient incentives at a strategic level to prioritise patient and public involvement.
]]>

document.description: Report presenting current and projected needs for mental health services and their related costs
document.body:
Recognising the significance of mental health in terms of both expenditure and the overall health of the population, the King’s Fund commissioned a review. This report presents current and projected needs for mental health services and their related costs. It gives details on a number of specific disorders, including depression, schizophrenic disorders and dementia. 'Paying the price' suggests that without the right level and type of investment we will all pay the price – not just in wasted resources but also in wasted lives. This report should be used to encourage informed debate about the future nature and shape of mental health support.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Commissioning]]>
document.title: PBC bulletin 4: service redesign and delivery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,PRIMARY CARE,SERVICE MODERNISATION,NHS STRUCTURES,NHS POLICY,COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING,SERVICE DEVELOPMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,ENGAGING CLINICIANS,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING]]>
document.body:
Local commissioning and decision-making - PBC moves power closer to the community and recognises the integration of health and social care;

LDP and Local Area Agreement priorities - should be used to drive PBC service planning;

Clinical engagement - engaging clinicians in the process is essential for successful transformational change;

Impact of the PbR tariff - learning about PbR tariff rules will ensure detailed accurate budgetary forecasting, recording and analysis;

Demand management – using demand management initiatives and techniques as a first step is more straightforward than planning new services;

Neutral locations - for community services may allow for greater usage of local facilities and assist in overcoming competitive barriers;

Contestability - ensuring PBC processes are consistent with the required governance and regulatory rules in relation to service tendering and provision.]]>

document.title: PBC bulletin 6: patients and the public
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,SERVICE SECTORS,COMMISSIONING,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,PATIENT AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,ENGAGING THE PUBLIC,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.body:
- Understanding the views of patients and the public is fundamental to both service development and a modern NHS.

- PCTs continue to have a statutory responsibility to consult patients and the public.

- Be clear about what the purpose is of involving patients and the public.

- Partnership approaches to Patient and Public Involvement (PPI) with other local organisations should be utilised where appropriate.

- Approaches to PPI may exist at different levels, there is no ‘one size fits all’.

- Governance arrangements for involving patients and the public need to be clear.]]>

document.title: PBC two years on: moving forward and making a difference?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: In 2007, a straw poll of GPs and practice managers by The King’s Fund and NHS Alliance found that primary care trusts (PCTs) were struggling to put in place the basic building blocks of practice-based commissioning (PBC). Two years on, has PBC moved forward and is it making a difference to patient care?
document.body: <![CDATA[ In 2007, a straw poll of GPs and practice managers by The King’s Fund and NHS Alliance found that primary care trusts (PCTs) were struggling to put in place the basic building blocks of practice-based commissioning (PBC). Two years on, has PBC moved forward and is it making a difference to patient care? A new poll has found continuing commitment to PBC and optimism about its potential but there is still lack of clarity at a local level about the purpose and vision for PBC. Moving into an era of restricted financial resources, it will become increasingly important for PCTs and practices to work together.]]>

document.title: PCT board development framework: specification
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,SERVICE SECTORS,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,DECISION MAKING,LOCAL LEADERS]]>
document.description: This document provides Primary Care Trusts with a specification that can be used at a local level to procure board development support.
document.body:
Primary Care Trust (PCT) board development has been identified as a key priority as part of the Department of Health’s world class commissioning programme. Following discussion with the ten Strategic Health Authorities (SHAs), the Department of Health (DH) has committed to leading this work at a national level. The board development work will include four main strands:

  1. publish a clear specification (this document) which PCTs can choose to use locally (and with other PCTs) to procure a board development programme;
  2. put in place a framework of pre-qualified providers with known ability to deliver the board development specification – by the end of August 2008;
  3. work with the NHS Institute for Innovation and Improvement to review their current PCT board development diagnostic tool and if necessary update this to fit more closely with world class commissioning - by the end of August 2008;
  4. publish a clear statement on the role and constitution of a PCT board, along with a model of good practice - in the summer of 2008.

The purpose of this document is to fulfil the first of the four strands outlined above, providing PCTs with a specification that can be used at a local level to procure board development support. The specification will also be used as the basis for the national board development framework. 

]]>

document.description: The Department of Health has commissioned the Association of Public Health Observatories (APHO) to develop a tool which helps commissioners to link health outcomes and expenditure. The development of this tool and a Spend and Outcome Factsheet for every PCT in England has been led by Yorkshire and Humber Public Health Observatory.
document.body:
Programme Budgeting is a well-established technique for assessing investment in programmes of care rather than services. All PCTs in England have submitted an annual programme budgeting return since 2003/4. The tool and factsheets use this Programme Budgeting data and overall indicators of health outcome by programme (where available) to present PCTs with an analysis of the impact of their expenditure. This allows easy identification of those areas which require priority attention, where relative potential shifts in investment opportunities will optimise local health gains and increase quality.

The ability to link expenditure and outcome is explicit in two of the World Class Commissioning competencies; '6 prioritise investment' and '11 make sound financial investments'.

PCTs can use the tool and the factsheets to gain an overview of outcome and expenditure across all programmes. The Department of Health programme budgeting spreadsheet allows further exploration of spend by programme and sub-programme.

NHS users can use the programme budgeting atlases to explore the relationship between spend and outcome within a programme.

You can choose to either download the Spend and Outcome Factsheet for your PCT or to go to the Spend and Outome Tool which allows you to explore the data in greater depth and to download the Spend and Outcome Factsheet for your PCT. We have produced a user guide, should you need help interpreting the charts in the profile.

document.title: PCTs as commissioners
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: Date reviewed: 10-09-08
document.body:
111-1PCTs as commissioners

Date reviewed: 10-09-08

 

 Definition

'Commissioning: the full set of services that local authorities and Primary Care Trusts (PCTs) undertake to make sure that the services funded by them, on behalf of the public are used to meet the needs of the individual fairly, efficiently and effectively.'

 

'2.4. Every PCT is reponsible for commissioning the full range of health services for its population, working in partnership with pratice-based commissioners. Most PCTS also directly provide many community health and other services and will continue to be free to do so, with appropriate governance arrangements which provide a proper distinction between their commissioning and providing functions.

 

2.6 As statutary bodies, PCT boards are responsible for securing the best possible services for their population within their allocated budget. PCTS cannot hand over the accountability for the commissioning functions to others; equally they cannot achieve their goals without close partnership with others such as local authorities. PCTs will need to work closely and effectively with primary care practices and other clinicians (including dentists, pharmacists, opticians and other front-line staff), patients and the public and local government.

 

2.8 PCTs will support the development of PBC by providing information, budgets, public health needs assessment, analysis of interventions and training and development for practices....'  (1).

Guidance/Tools

Department of Health Commissioning

World class commissioning

Joint strategic needs assessment

Improving quality in primary care (7 October 2009)

document.description: Perinatal mental health is now recognised as a major public health concern. Mental health problems during pregnancy, childbirth and postnatally can have an adverse effect on the mother-baby relationship and can impact on the child's development. Maternal mental health is one of the biggest indirect causes of maternal deaths in England. With recognition of the need to improve perinatal mental health services, questions were added to the 2009/2010 CSM exercise to establish a baseline of service provision in England.

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,SOCIAL CARE,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,NEEDS ASSESSMENT,CONTRACTING AND PROCUREMENT,POPULATIONS SERVED,ADULTS,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,STRATEGIC COMMISSIONING,JOINT COMMISSIONING,PROCUREMENT,THIRD SECTOR,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,PERSONALISED COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: This article alerts readers to significant changes in the delivery of public services.
document.body:
This article alerts readers to significant changes in the delivery of public services.

The personalisation agenda is driving huge changes in public services. It’s also about much more than changing or even transforming service systems and processes. At its heart it’s also about a fundamental change in the relationship between citizens, communities and the state. It therefore has important implications for the local third sector and local infrastructure organisations.

This paper outlines what the personalisation agenda is, explains key developments, discusses potential implications and considers what local infrastructure organisations can do.

]]>

document.title: Personalisation briefing for commissioners
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,COMMISSIONING,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,SOCIAL CARE,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,NEEDS ASSESSMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,STIMULATE THE MARKET,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,PERSONALISED COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: Smart commissioning is critical to achieving the vision spelled out in Putting People First. It requires a transformation in the commissioning role in terms of the investments commissioners make, the markets they work to shape and the relationships they seek to build to meet local needs.
document.body:
Smart commissioning is critical to achieving the vision spelled out in Putting People First. It requires a transformation in the commissioning role in terms of the investments commissioners make, the markets they work to shape and the relationships they seek to build to meet local needs.

Commissioning in a world of transformed social care is a different but no less important task. As councils disaggregate increasing proportions of their investments to individuals to make their own purchasing decisions, commissioners will need to find ways of working in partnership with providers to ensure a good range of choices and the right types of support for personal budget holders and self-funders. This will often mean a need for innovative services which better respond to individuals’ purchasing decisions.

There are two main tasks for commissioners delivering personalisation:

  • ensuring the right balance of investment between different services – aggregated and disaggregated investments
  • shaping the market – so that high-quality, flexible and responsive services are available for personal budget holders and self-funders

Both tasks must be underpinned by the Joint Strategic Needs Assessment (JSNA) and involve a co-productive approach to engaging people using services in their design, delivery and evaluation.Local Area Agreements are an important vehicle for securing the sign-up of partners to targets derived from the JSNA.

]]>

document.description: Tool for local councils with social services responsibilities with partners (such as mental health trusts). [No publication date available]
document.body:
This tool is for local councils with social services responsibilities with partners (such as mental health trusts). It aims to help them better understand what is required to transform social care systems from current models to a 'self-directed support' model that will support the delivery of the personalisation agenda. It draws on the learning so far from experience of implementing direct payments, the Individual Budget Pilot Programme and In Control. It aims to:

  • Help councils, partner agencies and organisations identify their progress to date, including achievements and areas where further scoping, planning and developmental work is required.
  • Suggest useful early activities and sources of guidance to increase their 'readiness' to embark.

This exercise fits alongside the Personalisation Toolkit which provides guidance and examples for councils embarking on transformation of their services to deliver personalisation.

[No publication date available]

]]>

document.title: Pharmaceutical Needs Assessments (PNAs) as part of world class commissioning: guidance for primary care trusts
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,COMMISSIONING,NEEDS ASSESSMENT,PHARMACY,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,NEEDS ASSESSMENT,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: Guidance for primary care trusts on how to produce PNAs in the broader context of world class commissioning.
document.body:
NHS Employers has developed new guidance for primary care trusts on how to produce PNAs in the broader context of world class commissioning. The guidance is aimed at directors of commissioning and pharmacy leads in PCTs, to help them develop a plan for how they will prepare their own PNA to deliver improved services for patients in their local area. It will also be of interest to providers of pharmaceutical services.

The guidance covers:

  • why and how PNAs should be integrated into PCTs' existing business and commissioning cycles
  • how PNAs fit within the world class commissioning framework
    the key pointers on how to write a PNA
  • how robust PNAs can be used to inform and sustain decisions on applications to provide services, and for workforce development
  • how PNAs can be used to support the provision of existing pharmaceutical services and extending the services that are provided by pharmacies
  • specific criteria and indicators of performance levels for the world class commissioning competencies particularly relevant for PNAs

 

]]>

111-1Practice based commissioning
Date reviewed: 17-02-10


Definition


'Practice based commissioning is about engaging practices and other primary care professionals in the commissioning of services....

Primary care trusts (PCTs) are the budget holders and have overall accountability for healthcare commissioning, however practice based commissioning (PBC) is crucial at all stages of the commissioning process.

In particular, practice based commissioners, working closely with PCTs and secondary care clinicians, will lead the work on deciding clinical outcomes. They also play a key supporting role to PCTs by providing valuable feedback on provider performance.' (1)


Guidance/Tools

including:
  • Practice based commissioning: guidance and resources

document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT,PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,PROGRAMME BUDGETING,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: The Department of Health has updated the toolkit that can be used to determine weighted capitation indicative budgets at practice level. This guidance sets out the changes.
document.body:
PCTs are responsible for ensuring that practices receive an indicative budget that reflects the needs of their population as accurately as possible. This allows a practice to access a 'fair share' of the resources available to the whole of the PCT for its patients. The Department of Health has updated the toolkit that can be used to determine weighted capitation indicative budgets at practice level. To accompany this toolkit, guidance has also been produced which sets out:

  • changes to the recommended methodology for deriving practices' fair shares for 2009/10
  • changes to the minimum pace of change to practices' budgets for 2009/10
  • information on how to use a new toolkit that can help PCT set budgets
]]>

document.title: Practice based commissioning in the National Health Service: interim report of a qualitative study
document.publisher: University of Manchester. National Primary Care Research and Development Centre
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING,PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,SERVICE SECTORS,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: A review of the activity of five Practice Based Commissioning consortia in three Primary Care Trusts.
document.body:
This report contains the results of a study of five Practice Based Commissioning (PBC) consortia in three 'early adopter' PCTs. Overall, it was found that PBC is becoming established in all of the study sites. A considerable amount of activity is taking place, and some changes in service organisation are beginning to occur and a diversity of organisational forms has been adopted.

The reorganisation of PCTs has delayed or complicated the development of PBC in some areas, and progress was greatest in the PCT that had not undergone reorganisation in 2006. GPs are engaging with the process, although this is variable, with small groups of highly motivated GPs leading in most consortia.

Some scepticism was found, particularly relating to whether or not PBC as a policy will last over time, but little active opposition was found, even among those idealogically opposed or not actively engaged.

Establishment of new working relationships was slow in some areas, and it is not yet clear whether the difficulties identified will be overcome in the longer term.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,WORKING COLLABORATIVELY]]>
document.description: Practice based commissioning resource for primary care pharmacists.
document.body:
Practice Based Commissioning (PBC) is the hot topic within primary care but what does it actually mean for pharmacists and what resources are there to help understand this new way of working? For many pharmacists, involvement in PBC will have been limited to date and many of the documents related to PBC do not recognise the valuable input that pharmacists can make in both the commissioning and the provision of services.

At a national level many representative bodies are lobbying for the involvement of pharmacists in PBC so now is a good time for pharmacists to get involved locally.

This document covers practice based commissioning, the benefits for pharmacists, the risks of not getting involved, what needs to happen locally, primary care pharmacy and useful links.

]]>

document.description: Discussion paper.
document.body:
Discussion paper.

Key points:

  • PbC was intended to increase the involvement of primary care clinicians in commissioning in order to improve local health services and health outcomes
  • the response to the PbC policy has been lukewarm
  • in a mature system, PbC would not be a separate policy area. Instead integrated clinical commissioning would be a core part of both PCT and practice business
  • to achieve this, debate around PbC needs to refocus on the outcomes it is intended to achieve
  • a set of principles for developing integrated clinical commissioning may help PCTs and practice based commissioners work together to deliver the vision for PbC

document.title: Practice based commissioning: reinvigorate, replace or abandon?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING,COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Practice-based commissioning (PBC) is one of the cornerstones of health policy reform, but has it delivered its intended benefits? Its objectives were to encourage clinical engagement in service redesign and development, improve services for patients and make better use of resources. Through in-depth interviews with GPs, hospital and primary care trust staff in four sites, this report assesses the progress of PBC and identifies the barriers that are limiting success. Using the evidence from the four case studies and from previous research, it suggests ways forward for policy-makers.]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ NHS ACTIVITIES,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING,NHS STRUCTURES,PRIMARY CARE,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,ENGAGING CLINICIANS,PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: This paper considers the current state of PBC implementation and how it might be driven forward within the NHS.
document.body:
The King's Fund and the NHS Alliance have published the results of a small sample poll of GPs and practice managers on the implementation of practice based commissioning. The key findings include:

- Only 3 per cent of respondents felt that their PCT involves them in strategic planning to a ‘great extent’ and 21 per cent to ‘some extent’.
- 33 per cent said that the support given to them by their PCT was ‘poor’ with only 30 per cent considering it ‘quite good’ or ‘very good’.
- Only 4 per cent found their PCT ‘very responsive’, but 19 per cent said that their PCT was ‘not at all’ responsive to issues raised by them.
- 70 per cent said that they had not agreed a budget for PBC with their PCT for the last financial year (2006/7). Of those who did have a budget, just under 60 per cent did not understand how it had been set.

The report concludes that there are a number of practical challenges to overcome first if PBC is going to be effective, such as ensuring GPs have access to accurate and timely data about costs and hospital usage, and keeping front-line clinicians engaged.

]]>

document.description: Objective was to develop and evaluate an evidence-based tool for predicting the likelihood of emergency admission to hospital of older people aged 75 years and over in the UK.
document.body: <![CDATA[ Practice based commissioners must recognise that admission-avoidance schemes need to feature heavily in their redesign plans and for these to work, they must be targeted at the right people, creating a need for a simple tool that predicts future risk of admission. This study develops and validates a simple to apply tool (EARLI) for identifying older people in the UK who are at risk of having an emergency admission within the following 12 months. ]]>

document.title: Preparing for GP Commissioning: legal and commercial issues
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,LEGAL AND TECHNICAL,GP COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: This special report from TPP Law provides some guidance on how GPs can plan for the opportunities ahead and highlights some of the risks and challenges to be addressed. This is a fast-moving policy environment: please bear in mind that the framework outlined in this document is subject to refinement and change as the proposals progress.
document.body:
The Conservative Lib-Dem Coalition Government released its long-term vision for the future of the NHS in July in the White Paper ‘Equity and Excellence: Liberating the NHS’. The Government has decided that, in order to shift decision-making as close as possible to individual patients, power and responsibility for commissioning services will be devolved to local consortia of GP practices. This change will bring together responsibility for clinical decisions and for the financial consequences of these decisions. This will reinforce the crucial role that GPs already play in committing NHS resources through their daily clinical decisions – not only in terms of referrals and prescribing, but also how well they manage long-term conditions, and the accessibility of their services.

In the light of these proposals, GPs will need to give thought to designing appropriate arrangements to respond to this new agenda. This special report from TPP Law provides some guidance on how GPs can plan for the opportunities ahead and highlights some of the risks and challenges to be addressed. This is a fast-moving policy environment: please bear in mind that the framework outlined in this document is subject to refinement and change as the proposals progress.

]]>

document.title: Primary care and community services: improving GP access and responsiveness
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,SERVICE SECTORS,QUALITY AND MONITORING,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,SERVICE PROVISION,QUALITY IMPROVEMENT,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,INNOVATION AND IMPROVEMENT,SYSTEMS THINKING,CHANGE MANAGEMENT,WHOLE SYSTEMS THINKING,LEADING IMPROVEMENT,CLINICAL SYSTEMS IMPROVEMENT,COMMUNITY AND DOMICILIARY SERVICES]]>
document.description: Part of the world class commissioning suite of practical guides, this document builds on existing good practice within the NHS to support PCTs in improving the accessibility and responsiveness of local GP services.
document.body:
This is part of a series of supportive guides to help Primary Care Trusts (PCTs) become world class commissioners of primary care services. They have been co-produced by NHS East of England, NHS Primary Care Commissioning (NHS PCC) and the Department of Health (DH).

This guide focuses on commissioning accessible and responsive GP practices and supports the previously published guide on improving the quality of commissioning GP services. It builds on, and should be read in conjunction with World Class Commissioning – Improving GP Services.

The guide provides practical advice on:

• mapping the baseline – how PCTs can assess their current performance on access

• developing the vision – how PCTs can craft a vision for the future

• making it happen – how PCTs, practices, the SHA and the Department can improve access.

The guide forms part of a rolling programme including other guides and a series of regional events. All are intended to support PCTs in addressing the strategic, leadership and operational challenges involved in driving up the quality of primary care commissioning and contracting.

]]>

document.description: In May 2009 the Department of Health commissioned the Primary Care Foundation to study the impact of using primary care within or alongside Accident and Emergency. The report highlights that use of primary care clinicians in Accident and Emergency departments can benefit patients where services are integrated and clinicians work together.
document.body:
In May 2009 the Department of Health commissioned the Primary Care Foundation to study the impact of using primary care within or alongside Accident and Emergency. The report highlights that use of primary care clinicians in Accident and Emergency departments can benefit patients where services are integrated and clinicians work together.

The findings of this report are being developed into a guide for commissioners on use of primary care clinicians with Accident and Emergency departments and this guide will be available soon.

This report will be of interest to NHS chief executives and their commissioning colleagues.

]]>

document.description: Examples of good practice around alcohol services in primary care. Can be adapted and used as a basis for an enhanced service via a schedule within a local primary care contract or Service Level Agreement.
document.body:
There are several Primary Care Service Frameworks available from PCC. Each Primary Care Service Framework is a generic, comprehensive and enhanced service specification for PCT commissioners and Practice Based Commissioners for 2007/08. These frameworks:

  • Help commissioners and providers consider, as a starting point, an integrated approach to enhanced service provision in primary care.
  • Describe the key requirements for a holistic, enhanced service – eg. appropriate processes, improvements in health outcomes, service inputs and outputs, staffing competencies, integrated governance, information etc.
  • Give an opportunity to consider which level of this enhanced service provision and contractual route(s) would be most appropriate to adopt locally, such as GMS, PMS, APMS or PCTMS , with the most appropriate providers available.

The purpose of this framework on alcohol services is:

  • to equip commissioners, providers and practitioners with the necessary background knowledge, service and implementation details to safely deliver support for alcohol interventions in primary care
  • as a means of improving the health and quality of life of people whose health may be compromised by their use of alcohol by providing patient-centred, systematic and ongoing support

More information on the framework and how it should be used can be found here.

 

]]>

document.description: Developed in the context of the Commissioning Framework, White Paper implementation, key national priorities and targets, and delivery mechanisms of Practice Based Commissioning. No publication date available.
document.body:
There are several Primary Care Service Frameworks available from PCC. Each Primary Care Service Framework is a generic, comprehensive and enhanced service specification for PCT commissioners and Practice Based Commissioners for 2007/08. These frameworks:

  • Help commissioners and providers consider, as a starting point, an integrated approach to enhanced service provision in primary care.
  • Describe the key requirements for a holistic, enhanced service – eg. appropriate processes, improvements in health outcomes, service inputs and outputs, staffing competencies, integrated governance, information etc.
  • Give an opportunity to consider which level of this enhanced service provision and contractual route(s) would be most appropriate to adopt locally, such as GMS, PMS, APMS or PCTMS , with the most appropriate providers available.

The purpose of this Primary Care Service Framework on vascular checks is: 

  • to equip commissioners, providers and practitioners with the necessary background knowledge, service and implementation details to safely deliver a high quality, integrated vascular checks service in primary care and the wider community setting
  • to improve the health and quality of life for people aged 40-74 by providing person-centred, systematic, integrated risk assessment and management

The framework has been designed quite deliberately to encourage innovation and flexibility on the part of the provider(s) and the part of the commissioner.

A performance tool is being developed to assist PCTs with the implementation and monitoring of this service

More information on the framework and how it should be used can be found here.


 

]]>

document.description: This guide focuses on the four primary statements and notes to the accounts, which make up part of PCT accounts, as specified by the PCT Manual for Accounts.
document.body:
NHS organisations have a statutory requirement to produce annual accounts (also known as financial statements) and an annual report. The PCT board is required formally to approve the accounts once they have been audited and therefore it is vital that Non-Executive Directors (NEDs) understand them. Alongside this formal requirement, understanding the annual accounts is imperative if NEDs are to fully appreciate the financial health of their organisation.

The format of the accounts is specified by the PCT Manual for Accounts and consists of: four primary statements (Operating Cost Statement; Balance Sheet; Cash Flow Statement; Statement of Recognised Gains and Losses); notes to the accounts; statement on internal control; directors' statement of responsibilities; and the auditor's report.

This guide focuses on the four primary statements and the notes to the accounts. Each primary statement and the key notes to the accounts are explained using an illustrative set of accounts. It is intended that NEDs will use the guide as a source of reference to look at if additional understanding is required for a particular aspect of the accounts. The guide also includes some questions that NEDs should consider before approving the annual accounts.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Commissioning]]>
document.title: Primary Care Trusts : tailoring commissioning
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,LOCAL LEADERS]]>
document.description: An NLGN white paper.
document.body:
Primary Care Trusts (PCTs) were created by the Department of Health  (DH) in 2002 to oversee the commissioning of primary care. As such, they commission 80% of healthcare, covering the services of GPs, dentists, opticians, pharmacists, and NHS walk-in centres. Their purpose was to achieve a greater degree of local freedom and decision-making power in health and well-being provision, to reduce health inequalities and improve the health of the community.

However many PCTs have struggled to fulfill these criteria. This paper argues that PCTs should be freed from central management control and national targets relaxed in order to empower local communities to play a greater role in defining the structure and priorities of their healthcare services.

]]>

document.title: Primary medical services contracts: a guide for potential contractors
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,COMMISSIONING,CONTRACT MANAGEMENT,CONTRACTING AND PROCUREMENT,NEGOTIATION AND INFLUENCING SKILLS,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: Guide aimed at new providers, including social enterprises or commercial companies, to offer services to registered patients alongside traditional general practice.
document.body:
One of the key objectives set out in the White Paper, 'Our health, our care, our say', is to secure better access to general practice.  In some places this will mean encouraging or allowing new providers, including social enterprises or commercial companies, to offer services to registered patients alongside traditional general practice.  This guide is aimed at those new providers, or potential primary medical services contractors.  

The guide offers an introduction to primary medical services contracting and the surrounding regulatory framework. It also provides helpful insights into the issues that potential contractors will have to consider and describes the process by which potential contractors might secure a primary care contract.

The guide also provides signposts to where more detailed information can be found. 

]]>

document.description: This guide is aimed at prioritisation coordinators.
document.body:
A guide designed to help PCTs identify and prioritise initiatives and build them into a comprehensive programme for change.

The NHS Institute for Innovation and Improvement has worked with a number of health communities across the country over the past two years to develop methods and approaches that will enable PCTs to build the necessary change to services into their local commissioning plans and then accelerate the spread and adoption of effective, evidence-based change across a wide range of services. One component is the strategic planning process (called Prioritise Commissioning Opportunities) detailed in this guide, which, along with the tools developed to support it, is designed to fit seamlessly into the work that your PCT will already have to undertake in order to create the Operating Plan.

Document/tools include: A range of techniques to identify and prioritise which initiatives will be taken forward into a comprehensive change programme.

Situation it works well in: The Prioritise Commissioning Opportunities process is undertaken by a multi-disciplinary team of 18-24 people from across the local health community.

Target audience: Prioritisation Coordinators

Note: Full access to this product is restricted to those with an NHS email address in England.

 

]]>
