document.description: This programme focuses on the workforce planning implications of commissioning health and/or social care services for a local health economy. No publication date available.
document.body:
This programme focuses on the workforce planning implications of commissioning health and/or social care services for a local health economy.

The programme has been developed to assist service commissioners, workforce planners and other managers who have responsibility for commissioning, planning, providing, managing or supporting the delivery of health and social care services.

Registration is required, however this is free. There is around an hour and a half of learning material on the disc broken into bite sized lessons. The user can work through the guide at their own pace as an educational resource or refer to it as a best practice guide when they are developing plans in the future.

The six modules are:

  • Module 1 – Health needs assessment (HNA)
  • Module 2 – Reviewing service provision
  • Module 3 – Deciding priorities
  • Module 4 – Designing services
  • Module 5 – Shaping the structure of supply
  • Module 6 – Managing demand

No publication date available.

]]>

document.body:
The new updated Child Health Promotion Programme (CHPP): pregnancy and the first five years of life builds on the children's National Service Framework and is intended to provide preventative services tailored to the individual needs of children and families, acting as a best practice guide for children's services.

The CHPP is a tool for supporting commissioners to meet obligations on breast feeding, obesity prevention, infant mortality and the 12-week antenatal assessment. document.title: Use of NICE appraised medicines in the NHS in England: experimental statistics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,COST EFFECTIVENESS,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) Technology Appraisal process assesses the clinical and cost effectiveness of new and existing medicines and treatments, and provides guidance on their use by the NHS. As part of the Pharmaceutical Price Regulation Scheme (PPRS) agreement, which became effective on 1 January 2009, the Department of Health (DH) and the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI) agreed to publish information on variation in the use in the NHS of selected medicines recommended by NICE.
document.body:
The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) Technology Appraisal process assesses the clinical and cost effectiveness of new and existing medicines and treatments, and provides guidance on their use by the NHS. As part of the Pharmaceutical Price Regulation Scheme (PPRS) agreement, which became effective on 1 January 2009, the Department of Health (DH) and the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI) agreed to publish information on variation in the use in the NHS of selected medicines recommended by NICE.

The NHS Information Centre was asked to produce a bulletin looking at the variation in use of these medicines in relation to the expected number of eligible patients as estimated by NICE. Data on the number of patients being treated is not available and so predicted use (using the expected number of eligible patients, the average dose and average length of treatment) was compared with observed use. Data on observed use in 2008 was taken from the primary care prescribing data (ePACT), and secondary care data (Hospital Pharmacy Audit Index). Data from the Prescribing Cost Analysis database was also used to look at long term trends in terms of cost.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,ACUTE SERVICES,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,SERVICE PROVISION,DISEASE/CONDITION GROUPS,DENTAL PROBLEMS,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,EMERGENCY AND URGENT CARE]]>
document.description: Prior to the introduction of the 2006 NHS dental contract in England and Wales, general dental practitioners (GDPs) were responsible for the provision of out-of-hours (OOH) emergency dental services (EDS); however there was great national variation in service provision. Under the contractual arrangements introduced 1st April 2006, local commissioning agencies became formally responsible for the provision of out-of-hours emergency dental services. This study aimed to examine patients' use of an out-of-hours emergency dental service and to determine whether the introduction of the 2006 national NHS dental contract had resulted in a change in service use, with a view to informing future planning and commissioning of care.
document.body:
Prior to the introduction of the 2006 NHS dental contract in England and Wales, general dental practitioners (GDPs) were responsible for the provision of out-of-hours (OOH) emergency dental services (EDS); however there was great national variation in service provision. Under the contractual arrangements introduced 1st April 2006, local commissioning agencies became formally responsible for the provision of out-of-hours emergency dental services. This study aimed to examine patients' use of an out-of-hours emergency dental service and to determine whether the introduction of the 2006 national NHS dental contract had resulted in a change in service use, with a view to informing future planning and commissioning of care.

The study has provided an insight into how and why people use an out-of-hours emergency dental service and has helped to guide future commissioning of these services. Overall, the service was being used in much the same way both before and after the 2006 dental contract. Significantly more use was being made of NHS Direct after April 2006; however, informal information networks such as friends and family remain an important source of information about accessing emergency dental services.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Commissioning]]>
document.title: Valuing Health Directly
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,PRIORITY SETTING,PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT,OUTCOMES,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: Decisions about which conditions and treatments to prioritise are never easy. Paul Dolan and colleagues argue that they should be based on people’s experiences rather than on what people think they might feel.
document.body:
Decisions about which conditions and treatments to prioritise are never easy. Paul Dolan and colleagues argue that they should be based on people’s experiences rather than on what people think they might feel.

Valuing the relative benefits of different treatments helps to allocate scarce healthcare resources to where they do the most good. The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) advises on the cost effectiveness of treatments and recommends that health benefits should be valued in terms of gains in quality adjusted life years (QALYs). This approach assigns a value between 0 (for death) and 1 (for full health) to each health state and then multiplies that value by how long the state lasts. It makes good sense to value health benefits by accounting for duration in this way.

The authors, however, have serious concerns about NICE’s recommendations for the "quality adjustment" part of the QALY. NICE suggests asking members of the general public to think about how many years of life they would be willing to trade to avoid different states of health. The authors feel that these hypothetical preferences often bear little relation to the real experiences of those in the health states. This article offers an alternative means of valuation that could help direct resources to treatments in proportion to the real suffering they alleviate.

 

]]>

document.description: Introduction to programme budgeting and marginal analysis.
document.body:
Introduction to programme budgeting and marginal analysis:

  • Programme budgeting and marginal analysis (PBMA) is a process that helps decision-makers maximise the impact of healthcare resources on the health needs of a local population.
  • Programme budgeting is an appraisal of past resource allocation in specified programmes, with a view to tracking future resource allocation in those same programmes.
  • Marginal analysis is the appraisal of the added benefits and added costs of a proposed investment (or the lost benefits and lower costs of a proposed disinvestment).

 

]]>

document.title: What is the financial risk in GP commissioning?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT,GP COMMISSIONING]]>
document.description: The financial risk associated with a fixed budget for the purchase of health care on behalf of a defined population (members of an insurance scheme, GP list, managed care organisation, etc) is a poorly understood area. The issues surrounding such risk fall under three broad categories, namely, the contribution of simple randomness and that of the weather and wider environment to higher volatility in costs; factors which contribute to financial asymmetry, i.e. why some experience higher cost pressures than others arising from the funding formula and local acute costs arising from the HRG tariff and finally from the trajectory of general healthcare costs relative to funding. The essential question, to which there is not a definitive answer, is whether GPs can reduce costs to a sufficient degree to ensure a long-term profit in the face of high inherent uncertainty and volatility in both present and future costs.

document.title: When politics and markets collide: reforming the England National Health Service
document.publisher: University of Birmingham. Health Services Management Centre
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SERVICE DEVELOPMENT,DEMAND MANAGEMENT,MARKET MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,COMMISSIONING,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,STIMULATE THE MARKET]]>
document.description: This paper looks at the challenges involved in ensuring that the design of the emerging market is appropriate and in reconciling the logic of a system driven by competition but overseen by politicians.
document.body:
The implication of the post election reappraisal is that provider competition will become an even more important driver of reform in future, and national targets and performance management will become less significant. Competition will be stimulated by the policy of extending the range of choices available to patients and by introducing greater plurality among providers, using Payment by Results. 

The theory behind the reforms is that empowering patients and encouraging new providers into the market will create a dynamic for improvement from within the NHS, thereby enabling politicians to be less involved in micro managing change. The challenge in implementing this theory is to ensure that the design of the emerging market is appropriate and to reconcile the logic of a system driven by competition.

Reforms to the NHS are using patient choice and provider competition to drive improvements in performance. In completing the design of the reforms, the government faces the challenge of ensuring that commissioners can negotiate on equal terms with providers and that appropriate arrangements are put in place for market management and regulation. Politicians also face the challenge of dealing with NHS providers that go into difficulty. 

This paper examines these issues.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Commissioning]]>
document.title: Who's accountable for health?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,COMMISSIONING,PATIENT AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.body:
Published in June 2008, this report focuses on local accountability and public involvement in the planning, purchasing and delivery of healthcare in England. It defines accountability and differentiates it from public involvement, and it considers how these concepts operate now - and could operate in future - across the domains of health service commissioning, healthcare provision and public health.

The evidence taken by the LGA Health Commission strongly suggests that there is currently no appetite for further major upheaval in the governance, structures or boundaries of the healthcare system. However it was also clear that local accountability for local decision-making was weak.

The Health Commission has sought practical recommendations that build on existing reforms and are designed to strengthen the mechanisms of local accountability, while recognising that for the foreseeable future there will be both a national and a local dimension to the governance.

]]>

document.title: Whose NHS is it anyway? Sharing the power with patients and the public
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMMISSIONING,PATIENT AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,DECISION MAKING,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,ENGAGING THE PUBLIC,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: This report is a detailed plan of action on engagement across the NHS.
document.body:
This report is a detailed plan of action on engagement across the NHS. The reports five main recommendations are:

1. More shared decisions in the consulting room – greater support for initiatives that allow patients to take more control if they want it. Shared decision making and people focused skills need to be a stronger theme in professional training and regulation.

2. GP surgeries to be more responsive to their local populations – closer engagement between GP practices and their patients, communities and LINks, supported by more sensitive regulation and monitoring.

3. More responsive and accountable commissioning. Commissioning, whether through primary care trusts (PCTs) or practice based commissioning (PBC) clusters, will be more effective if it involves patients and communities.

4. A stronger push at national level to share power with patients and citizens, government, regulators and professions do more to promote shared decision making for individual patients, including more community participation in the NHS, and a more listening and responsive service.

5. Explore co-production of services – this could offer a new vision of how primary care could design, deliver and monitor improved health care, in collaboration with the population it serves, through users groups, LINks and the voluntary sector.

]]>

document.title: WiPP National Self Care Conference: commissioning self care for life
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,GENERAL,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,COMMUNITY AND DOMICILIARY SERVICES,WORKING COLLABORATIVELY,ENGAGING THE PUBLIC,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES]]>
document.description: Report of the conference, held on 31 October 2007.
document.body:
On 31 October 2007, the NHS Working in Partnership Programme (WiPP) hosted a national conference on self care, with a focus on investing in self care. It brought together health professionals, practitioners and policy makers for a day of discussion and debate, built around the seven ages of health: infancy, childhood, adolescence, young adulthood, working life, retirement and end of life - theming which aimed to illustrate that self care is about the whole of life, rather than just managing long term conditions or the end of life.

The conference marked the launch of the NHS Working in Partnership Programme’s online self care resource and networking organisation, Self Care Connect. 

The conference also raised the following points:

  • today’s sedentary lifestyles will cost the NHS billions of pounds in the future, so people must be supported in making healthier lifestyle choices;
  • self care leads to reduced utilisation of health services in both primary and secondary care, more appropriate use of medicines, and shorter and less acute episodes of chronic conditions;
  • self care services can be commissioned at all stages of life. Seven initiatives and services were explored by delegates in a series of workshops themed around the seven ages of man.

At the end of the day, 100% of delegates said they believed self care support services were worth investing in, compared with 83% at the start of the day.

 

]]>

document.body:
Videos and resources from the virtual conference for world class commissioning assurance - launch of Year 2.

Nearly 400 SHA and PCT CEOs, chairs, PEC chairs and key partners gathered in London on 16 September to hear about the refined assurance framework for Year 2.

Gary Belfield, acting director general of Commissioning & System Management (DH), chaired the day, supported by a video message from David Nicholson, NHS chief executive. An expert panel took questions from the floor and two PCT CEOs discussed the impact of WCC on PCT commissioning.

Interactive seminar sessions included: strengthening community partnerships, working effectively with providers to stimulate the market and robust analysis of spend and its impact on health benefit.

Attendees each received a copy of the WCC assurance handbook for Year 2. This is a guide for PCTs and SHAs that explains WCC assurance in detail. In the same way as last year, PCTs can access the handbook and accompanying soft copy documentation on the WCC toolkit.

NHS commissioning teams and other interested parties are invited to watch this event online. You can:

  • Watch the keynotes, panel discussion and interactive workshop sessions
  • Download presentations, podcasts and associated documentation, vital for your role
  • Gather practical support to develop your strategic commissioning skills and capabilities

WCC Data Packs are produced on behalf of the Department of Health to support PCTs during the World Class Commissioning (WCC) assurance process.

This online resource brings together data from multiple sources to provide a profile of your organisation and national averages to help monitor trends and make comparisons. With the ability to manipulate data for local requirements and benchmarking for national, regional and most comparable PCT activity.

Covering some 250 indicators, the 2009/10 data packs are designed to help PCTs prepare for the second round of the WCC panel assessments in early 2010. The data is regularly refreshed therefore providing an essential resource for commissioners throughout the entire commissioning cycle.

For more information and resources on The WCC Data Packs please visit www.ic.nhs.uk/wccdatapacks.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ TOOLKITS,PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT,PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT,FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,GENERAL,COMMISSIONING,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.description: Online toolkit including the guidance, tools and templates required to support commissioning assurance and the creation of PCT plans.
document.body:
This web-based toolkit contains resources to support 'commissioning assurance'.

'Commissioning assurance' is the system for world class commissioning. It will stand within the established annual cycle as a consistent assurance system to review Primary Care Trust (PCT) progress towards world class performance and achievement of better health outcomes. It will be delivered and managed by Strategic Health Authorities (SHAs) and will provide a common basis for agreeing further development.

This toolkit includes the guidance, tools and templates required to support commissioning assurance and the creation of PCT plans.

The 'Commissioning assurance' section includes the guidance, tools and templates to support PCTs and SHAs to perform the assessment. It is split into four sections:

  • handbook, which provides guidance on the content and process of commissioning assurance;
  • PCT preparation, which contains the templates for PCTs to complete the five steps they need to perform before the panel day; 
  • panel preparation, which provides guidance and automated reports both to support the creation of panel briefings and to upload them; 
  • output and follow-up, where panel reports may be accessed and where ratings will be published.

The 'PCT plans' section includes guidance and templates to support the creation of PCT strategic plans, assisting with the development of both the long term financial plan and the organisation development plan.

PCTs and SHAs will have access to additional, password-protected areas of the web site.

 

]]>

document.description: This publication contains a brief overview of ‘Your health, your way – a guide to long term conditions and self care’ for social care professionals. document.body:
This publication contains a brief overview of ‘Your health, your way – a guide to long term conditions and self care’ for social care professionals. It discusses the concept of personalised support planning for people with long term conditions (LTCs) and supported self care with points for consideration when starting the support planning process.

 
The paper discusses a range of health and social care enterprises and takes account of Our Health, Our Care, Our Say: a new direction for community services, the White Paper on community health and social care published at the end of January 2006. A “future gazing” exercise and a discussion activity for commissioning boards are found at the end of the paper. These are designed to stimulate discussion about the future disposition of health and social services in specific geographical areas.

]]>
